title: Will the Raspberry Pi 4 support Ubuntu 20.10? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are a number of problems with this question: Raspberries use ARM chipsets and therefore an instruction set other than desktop chipsets like Intel or AMD. So, you can’t just take over Ubuntu from desktop to your Raspberry. That’s not how it works.20.10 is an intermediate release between long-term releases, that is only supported for 9 months. As a normal user you shouldn’t use it at all. As a desktop user you should stick with the long-term support releases. Even though, those show many glitches these days, that’s your safest bet as a user with Ubuntu. You should only use the short-term releases as a system developer. Given the nature of the question, you shouldn’t use it.Ubuntu does run on Raspberries but is very limited. It looks nice on the surface, but when I used it on ARM, it didn’t even come with basics like an image viewer. Ubuntu is quite limited. There are better options. Raspbian is obviously one of them. Another one and the one I use most would be Arch Linux for ARM chipsets. Next to another few that come with solid support and feature sets.So, it might be available for Raspberries or it might not be. But be it as it may, it’s a poor choice. It’s Ubuntu, it’s short-term and it’s not for production use. The nature of the question doesn’t exactly suggest, that you are an Ubuntu system developer for either Raspberries OR desktop. So, the recommendation has to be, to use a better option.

There’s a comprehensive answer to this question, by Chris Bailey, which enlightened my understanding of the subject, but I want also to indicate that Ubuntu Server 20.04 LTS seems to be fully supported on Raspberrry PIs, as you can see on this page: Install Ubuntu Server on a Raspberry Pi 2, 3 or 4 | Ubuntu If you choose so, after downloading, writing the image to a SD card, booting the Pi, configuring… , you can then install one of the available desktop interfaces. I did that some time ago, and I had problems with Gnome and/or KDE. Perhaps LXDE or some other lightweight should work better. But you’re at your own risk!
